{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7085858/grasshopper-mountain-trail-1580", "title": "Grasshopper Mountain Trail #1580", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.055399,-122.507522", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7085858", "info-text": {"description": "This trail leaves the Grasshopper Trail #1574 and travels easily upward for less than a mile to the summit of Grasshopper Mountain and the former site of a fire lookout. The trail receives some maintenance and is easy to follow to within 500 horizontal feet of the top. Here it grows faint as it crosses a shallow bowl filled with grasses. The trail becomes readily apparent again on the other side of this bowl.\r\n\nA fire lookout camp had been set on top of Grasshopper in 1912 and a cupola cabin was built there in 1925. This was followed in 1933 by an L-4 cab which was replaced in 1958 by a 10-foot R-6 flat cab (the parts of which were lifted to the summit by helicopter). All the structures were removed in 1977. All that remains today are the four concrete foundations of the 1958 lookout.", "features": "Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7062437/buckeye-lake-l-and-cliff-lake-r-from-the-summit-of-grasshopper-mountain", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5354, 4981], "alt-change": [373, 228], "avg-grade": 16.0, "max-grade": 45.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7086531/donegan-prairie-trail-1431", "title": "Donegan Prairie Trail #1431", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.91781,-122.589682", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7086531", "info-text": {"description": "This trail allows you to visit large meadows, a rare dry meadow community, and large stands of 300-400 year-old Shasta firs and mountain hemlock.\r\n\nIt has a 2-star rating at present (Fall 2019) because its southern half suffers from lack of maintenance and damage from a wildfire in 2017. If the trail is maintained and the fire damage repaired, it would easily merit a 3-star rating.\r\n\nStarting from the eastern trailhead, the first 1.5 miles of trail (which is in good condition and easy to follow) passes through relatively open forest and several large, attractive moist meadows. These are filled with spectacular wildflowers from late June through August. At the western end of the last big meadow, the trail becomes obscured by low-growing bushes. Turn around here if your goal was just to see the meadows and the wildflowers.\r\n\nBetween 1.5 and 2.5 miles from the northern trailhead, the trail passes through a younger forest and a dry meadow community. As of Fall 2019, this section had received no maintenance and was hard to follow due to low-growing bushes and some fallen trees.\r\n\nAt about 2.5 miles, the trail traverses a stand of large incense cedars and Douglas firs that was burned by a spot wildfire in 2017. The trail is very hard to follow through here so contour into the Dead Horse Creek drainage and pick-up the trail again where it crosses the creek.\r\n\nOnce past the creek, the trail becomes easier to follow (except for a few fallen trees) as it climbs to its end at its western trailhead on Forest Road 800. Hike back to the northern trailhead from here along FR 800 or, if you have an appropriate vehicle, arrange for a shuttle.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7063369/another-large-meadow-along-the-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 4.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5391, 5073], "alt-change": [645, 635], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 43.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025912/alder-springs-trail-855", "title": "Alder Springs Trail #855", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.4333,-121.357562", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025912", "info-text": {"description": "With just a little effort and some wet feet, this trail ushers hikers into a wonderful, high-desert environment full of flowing water and powerful rock formations. Descend to the banks of the Whychus Creek and then follow it to the Deschutes River for a rewarding finish.\r\n\nFrom the trailhead, travel down the clear trail through the scattered trees to cross to the adjacent ridge. Over the next few miles, the singletrack works its way along the ridge, revealing an occasional glimpse of the creek. Eventually, the trail drops past a dry waterfall to descend to the clear waters of Whychus Creek. This is the first up-close opportunity to appreciate the large rock formations that make up the layered bluffs in the area, and it's worth a pause. \r\n\nGet ready, as the lush vegetation ahead surrounds a bridgeless creek crossing. Those not wanting to get wet should turn around. Otherwise, wade across the water to reach the other bank. The water flow is generally greater in the spring and early summer.\r\n\nContinuing on, the narrow and sometimes-rocky trail rises away from the creek until it returns to the bank for a final, gradual descent down to the confluence with the Deschutes River. The roaring water and shade from nearby ponderosas make a great spot to enjoy a snack or lunch.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7073291/end-of-the-trail-at-the-deschutes-river", "ratings": {"rating": 4.7, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 2.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2597, 2109], "alt-change": [158, 643], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 22.0}},

For the first few miles, the creek only runs in the winter months. But in the summer, you can hear the water running under the lava rock bead. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034862/lawler-trail-3473", "title": "Lawler Trail #3473", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.759121,-122.619318", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034862", "info-text": {"description": "Lawler starts as a rolling climb followed by a gentle descent to the intersection with the Patterson Mountain Viewpoint Connector. The out and back is worth the effort for the trail and the view.\r\n\nFrom the intersection, the trail contours a bit more and then starts the real descent. The trail surface changes often as it alternates between tight turns and straight line steep sections; one minute you'll be hiking smooth dirt and then next you'll be making your way across loose and chunky terrain. \r\n\nAfter the second road crossing there is a short, steep section to reach a craggy ridge. After topping out, enjoy the views before the next downhill sections that cover both sides of the ridge.\r\n\nLawler now continues by way of a new connection, built in 2016/2017, adding two more miles.  The newer section is mostly machine built featuring mellower grades, with sweeping corners and short sections with rocky footing.  The trail changes character as it approaches Duval Creek with steeper grades.  As you descend toward FS Road 531 the trail passes through old growth forest where you'll want to watch your step because of the abundance of roots on the trail.\r\n\nPop out onto FS 531 and hike down the road for 100 feet to pick up the trail (on your left) again, or hike a mile of road to the intersection of Patterson Mountain Road/531 where most people park a shuttle vehicle.\r\n\nIf you choose to continue down to Highway 58 by trail, stay left on South Willamette #3465 and hike about two miles over rolling contours and through several creek crossings. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034639/alpine-3450", "title": "Alpine #3450", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.901126,-122.465355", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034639", "info-text": {"description": "Alpine starts at the intersection of FS 1912 and FS 1825 and mostly climbs through classic Oregon forests to Kate's Cut-In where most people start Alpine.\r\n\nStart from the road and turn left onto Kate's Cut-In. There will be a quick switchback to the right and then you'll have a short climb to the Alpine intersection. Turn left again. The trail climbs gradually through big trees to a large grassy meadow. Enjoy a brief flat section before diving back into trees, rolling towards the first sustained descent. The crossing of a short narrow ridge signifies a steep descent ahead.\r\n\nThis section ends at a road, cross and reach an uphill section that leads to another big downhill nicknamed 'Jedi'. This dark and steep section of forest ends at Windy Pass, a major road intersection.\r\n\nFrom here there is a relatively short and easy climb through a new section. It ends at yet another road. From here you'll be on a rehabbed road, now a trail, that climbs through a series of surfaced 's' turns.\r\n\nThere's a brief respite and then the route continues to climb. The forest opens up to big trees and steep, lush, lichen-leaden side slopes to an incredible view at a high meadow. This is a great place to stop for a snack break and take in the views.\r\n\nFrom here Alpine rolls past the Tire Mountain intersection (turn right here if hiking A-T-C-A) and then descends continuously through beautiful forest down to the Buckhead Shelter with only a few slight uphills along the way.\r\n\nFrom the shelter, there's another round of brief climbing followed by sustained descent to a road. After crossing, you'll experience another descent, one of the the roughest on Alpine with tight turns and some scrabbly texture.\r\n\nAfterward, your knees will get a break as you reach flatter terrain. The trees are beautiful through here, covered in multi-hued lichens up and down their trunks.\r\n\nStay straight through multiple road crossings then dive into a narrow trail. At the last intersection, make a hard left onto the Westfir Tie and reach the finish at the bottom of the road. Turn right to take it easy on the back to the parking lot at the red bridge.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7059333/one-of-the-few-viewpoints-along-the-trail-looking-southeast-to-diamond-peak", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 15.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4773, 1121], "alt-change": [1922, 4519], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 36.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035128/tire-mountain-3485", "title": "Tire Mountain #3485", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.828303,-122.497677", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035128", "info-text": {"description": "Tire Mountain is a must-do route. It's got amazing scenery, an great descent through a huge pine forest and narrow singletrack throughout.  The trail is best hikeed from Alpine to Cloverpatch.\r\n\nThe upper end of Tire Mountain starts from Alpine, just after the big open meadow view.  The trail climbs quickly from the intersection and then descends into a thick forest of oaks and green, lichen covered boulders.  The route climbs gradually overall with short ups and downs.\r\n\nAfter the beginning sections of the trail, the views open up to steep grassy hillsides with rock cliffs and fins.  You'll traverse this for a bit and feel like you're in the Highlands of Scotland.\r\n\nAs you dive back into the lush forest, the big descent begins. It's quite possibly the biggest pine forest you've ever seen.  It's a fun and sustained descent following several turns and switchbacks.  \r\n\nThe bottom reaches of the trail roll a little less steeply.  Look for an intersection with Cloverpatch on the left as the route makes a big left turn around the nose of a slope. The route has been re-located in several places to avoid forest roads. When the trail hits a road, the next section isn't far ahead. Just in case, be sure to take a map or consult the Hiking Project mobile app when signage isn't available.\r\n\nDespite its smooth and loamy nature, the route itself is difficult due to endless climbing (with some steep grades) and descending with plenty of switchbacks.\r\n\nWinberry Divide can be done as an out-and-back or combined with Alpine and Tire Mountain as a point-to-point hike.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 4.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2785, 2116], "alt-change": [1292, 674], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 48.0}},

The trailhead is located along the Wild and Scenic North Umpqua River and the campground is designed to accommodate pack and saddle use as well as standard camping. Although primarily intended as an equestrian trail, the #1412 does afford hikers and backpackers the means to access other trails in the area and also to form loops. It also provides access to the northern part of the Mount Thielsen Wilderness.\r\n\nDue to the horse traffic, the lower parts of the #1412 can be soft and dusty, but hikers should stick it out in anticipation of better trails ahead. About 0.3 miles from the trailhead, the #1412 reaches a junction with the Porcupine Connect Trail #1412A which can be used to access the North Umpqua Trail #1414.\r\n\nThe trail continues to climb gradually through the open forest crossing a couple of creeks. At about 1.5 miles from the trailhead, the #1412 reaches a junction with the Tenas Peak Trail #1445. From there, there are no more trail junctions on the Windigo Pass Trail as it continues easily on up to the head of the Bradley Creek drainage, swings east, parallels Forest Road 60 for awhile, and comes to an end at Forest Road 60-501 at Windigo Pass. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7046080/tipsoo-peak-trail-1472", "title": "Tipsoo Peak Trail #1472", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.223684,-122.067545", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7046080", "info-text": {"description": "Tipsoo is the Chinook word for \"grass\" or \"hair\". This peak is unique for two reasons: (1) it's an 8,000-foot peak that is reachable via a pretty short and nicely graded trail and (2) the treeline extends to within a few feet of its red cindery summit (elsewhere in the Cascades the treeline is usually between 6,000 and 7,000 feet).\r\n\nAccess to the trailhead is via Cinnamon Butte Road (Forest Road 4793) off of Highway 138. At 1.6 miles from the highway, Forest Road 4793 turns sharply left to climb to the lookout, while you continue straight ahead on Forest Road 4793-100. Continue on this gravel road for 3.6 miles to the trailhead. The last 0.5 miles is bumpy dirt but should be passable by a 2WD car. If not, park and hike up the road to the trailhead. There is a small sign marking the trailhead.\r\n\nThe #1472 starts up a series of wide switchbacks traversing through a forest of widely-spaced mountain hemlocks and true firs with little ground vegetation. After about a mile, the trail enters Mount Thielsen Wilderness. At about 2.5 miles from the trailhead, the trail breaks into more open ground with meadows and stunted trees, then climbs gently into open dry meadows. You'll have your first views of Mount Thielsen too south from here. The final 300 feet to the top is an easy second-class scramble along a narrow rocky ridge of dark maroon volcanic rock. Views from the top are spectacular and include Diamond Peak, Miller and Maidu Lakes, Mount Bailey, Howlock Mountain, Mount Thielsen, and other Cascade peaks to the north and south.\r\n\nAdventurous hikers can make the short (0.3 mile) easy scramble down the southeast side of the peak to meet up with the PCT. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7024607/north-umpqua-trail-1414", "title": "North Umpqua Trail #1414", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.333386,-123.005216", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7024607", "info-text": {"description": "The North Umpqua Trail is 79 miles long. The trail is split into twelve sections ranging from 3.6 to 13.0 miles long, with various levels of difficulty. Numerous other trails, including the PCT, intersect the North Umpqua Trail. Trailheads for each section are easily accessed and clearly marked.\r\n\nThe following sections are CLOSED as of Sep 2020 due to the Archie Creek Fire:\r\nSwiftwater: 8.3 miles\r\nTioga: 7.4 miles\r\nMott: 5.5 miles\r\nPanther: 5.0 miles\r\n\nThe following sections remain OPEN:\r\nCalf: 3.7 miles\r\nMarsters: 3.6 miles\r\nJessie Wright: 4.1\r\nDeer Leap: 9.6\r\nHot Springs: 3.5\r\nDread and Terror: 13.0 miles\r\nLemolo: 6.3 miles\r\nMaidu: 9.0 miles\r\n\nEach section of the trail has a different look and feel, and most can be done as out-and-back hikes. The longer sections (Deer Leap and Dread and Terror) are best completed as one-way hikes. The 9-mile Maidu section, if done as a one-way hike, requires a long drive to Miller Lake to either start or end the hike.\r\n\nWestern portions of the trail can typically be done year-round, but snow can be expected in winter at the higher elevations as you head east along the North Umpqua River.\r\n\nThe trail parallels the North Umpqua River, occasionally taking minor detours away from the river, climbing mostly gentle hills and providing lofty views of the river from above. Numerous creeks are traversed by small footbridges. The majority of the trail is through dense forest, comprised of Douglas-fir, hemlock, and sugar pine. Lodgepole and ponderosa pine are common at higher elevations. Wildflowers can be spectacular in the spring, and green moss abounds year-round as it clings to moisture-rich soil, fallen trees and large strewn boulders. Various types of mushrooms and other fungi also thrive in this environment.\r\n\nThe trail is moderately maintained. Expect downed trees and/or trail slide-outs after major storms or snowfall. It may take some time for crews to go in and clear trees off of the trail. Local Ranger Districts encourage hikers to report major trail issues.\r\n\nVegetation overgrowth is typically not a problem, presence of poison oak is minimal. Ticks are usually not an issue, but can be present during warm, dry weather.\r\n\nFacilities: There are vault toilets at most of the trailheads.\r\n\nConveniences with groceries, gas, and/or dining as you travel from west to east along HWY 138:\r\nIdleyld Trading Post, Steamboat Inn, Dry Creek Store, Lemolo Lake KOA, Diamond Lake Resort", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7044995/the-trail-goes-under-a-penstock", "ratings": {"rating": 4.7, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 77.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [6073, 791], "alt-change": [9626, 4384], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 36.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7048986/mount-thielsen-trail-1456", "title": "Mount Thielsen Trail #1456", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.146242,-122.127355", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7048986", "info-text": {"description": "This trail leads from the Mount Thielsen Trailhead (and Sno-Park) to the Mount Thielsen. Its primary use is as the approach route for a climb of Mount Thielsen. It can also be used to form a nice loop from the Howland Mountain Trailhead through Timothy Meadows to the PCT and back. This is a popular summer hike/climb and this trailhead can be busy on weekends and holidays.\r\n\nFrom the trailhead, the #1456 through lodgepole pine for the first mile and reaches a junction with the Spruce Ridge Trail #1458 after 1.5 miles. An excellent view of Mt. Thielsen presents itself just beyond this trail junction. Past here, the trail turns briefly south then swings west below the west ridge of Point 6832. At 2.8 miles from the trailhead, it makes a brief turn to the north and then follows Thielsen's northwest ridge to a junction with the PCT at 3.6 miles. Up to this point, the #1456 has been an established trail with a clear and easy tread.\r\n\nFrom the PCT, the #1456 proceeds up the ridge as an obvious scramble trail (this is a popular climb that sees a lot of use). Most of this portion of the #1456 is a steep hike up loose, dusty scree and small rocks - tedious but not difficult. There is some Class 2/3 scrambling just before you reach a small notch (\"Chicken Ledge\") about 80-feet below the actual summit of Thielsen. The views on the way up to this point are usually excellent and the notch makes a good goal for those not seeking the summit.\r\n\nFrom the notch on the southeast side of the pinnacle, you can see the 80-foot climb/scramble up the south face to the summit. Wear on the rock in spots points the way to go but just pick the easiest way up. The start is right in the notch and you angle slightly left as you climb. There may be a of couple Class 4 moves with exposure but the rock is fairly solid and blocky (but always test your hand and footholds first!). Most climbers don't protect this 80-foot section but whether you do so or not depends on your comfort/experience level. It's easy to rappell off the summit, so if you feel better protecting and rapping, do as a slip could mean injury or death. Also avoid getting too close to the right side of the south face, as the exposure over there is severe and the wind, which frequently whips across the ridge, can throw you off balance.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7046002/the-north-face-of-mount-thielsen-from-howlock-mountain", "ratings": {"rating": 4.4, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 4.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [8714, 5436], "alt-change": [3278, 321], "avg-grade": 15.0, "max-grade": 121.0}},

Either way you access it, there is no bridge across Eagle Creek, and it will require fording this wilderness creek. \r\n\nTo get to the Estacada side of the trail (south end), from Hwy 224, turn left (east) onto Fall Creek Road and follow it for 0.4 mile to Divers Road. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7021977/green-canyon-way-trail-793a", "title": "Green Canyon Way Trail #793A", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.282737,-121.941638", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7021977", "info-text": {"description": "Green Canyon Way Trail begins along Salmon River Road across the road from Green Canyon Campground and is a long steady climb with numerous switchbacks to the ridge line of Hunchback Mountain. While the forest vegetation is thick and luscious, the views for this steep slog are few and far between. It is a great shady hike on a hot, summer day. Many of the trees are pistol butted because of the steep unstable soils on the slopes.\r\n\nThis trail gets little use and is not routinely maintained. There has been significant blow down which has not all been logged out. Some climbing over logs will be necessary. In addition, blow down near the top of the trail has taken out part of the trail tread requiring a traverse. Trail access on the north end is off of Highway 26 on SE Wildcat Creek Road, that has been gated, requiring a 3+ mile hike past the gate to the trail. \r\n\nMost hikers access the trail from the south end by parking at the Douglas Trailhead on Wildcat Mountain. The trail then hits the Douglas Trail intersection where you head east for 1.4 miles towards the peak of Wildcat Mountain and the intersection with McIntyre Trail. Stop to admire views of Eagle Creek canyon to the south and the rest of the Salmon-Huckleberry Wilderness. After hiking the 1.7 miles to the McIntyre Ridge intersection, hikers can hike the entire 6.6 miles of the northern trailhead for McIntyre Ridge, but most hike just a few miles along the ridge line and then return the way they came.  \r\n\nFrom the Douglas Trail #781, turn left (north) onto McIntyre Ridge Trail #782 and follow the ridgeline trail. If it is spring or summer, there are likely oodles of bear grass and rhododendron in bloom. Several other openings and wildflower meadows can be found along this trail. The trail varies from thick forest, to peek-a-boo views, to openings with stunning vistas. The trail is relatively level for the first 1.5 miles and then drops over 1,200 feet for the next 2.7 miles to the northern trail terminus. Once at the point, you can take a trail down to the beach or explore the rocky ridge at the point. This trail does flood pretty heavily in the wet months, so it's best to wait until it is close to dry before attempting the hike. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7043900/blacklock-point-connector-trail", "title": "Blacklock Point Connector Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.881189,-124.522929", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7043900", "info-text": {"description": "The trail to Blacklock Point starts at a trailhead at the end of Airport Road at the Cape Blanco State Airport. Approximately 0.9 miles north along this trail (which is actually an old road), you'll come to a junction. The trail to Blacklock Point veers left (west) here, while the Blacklock Point Connector Trail (also an old road) continues straight ahead (north).\r\n\nThe usual hike is to turn left here and follow signs out to the impressive views from the point. After that, you return to a junction with the Floras to Blacklock Connector and follow that north past three viewpoints along the top of the cliffs. About 1.2 miles north on the Floras to Blacklock Connector, you'll come to another junction. Going left (north) here will keep you on the Floras to Blacklock Connector toward Floras Lake, while turning right (south) will put you on the Blacklock Point Connector Trail for a short hike back to Blacklock Point and the trailhead near the airport.\r\n\nThe purpose of this connector is to allow you to enjoy the views from Blacklock Point without having to commit to hiking to Floras Lake and without having to do much backtracking.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7041730/going-south-on-the-blacklock-point-connector-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 1.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [195, 132], "alt-change": [64, 1], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},

The Salal Hill trailhead is at east end of the parking lot. The trail is an out-and-back route with a mild climb. There are great views of the Yaquina Head Lighthouse to the west. In the summer, you may see bald eagles that prey on nesting seabird chicks. Keep an eye towards the ocean and you'll likely see spouting whales. \r\n\nAt the top of Salal Hill, you can look back towards Newport and find various landmarks such at the the Yaquina Bay Bridge and the Lighthouse at the Yaquina River bar. After going back down the hill, be sure to explore the Yaquina Head Lighthouse, Cobble Beach (below the lighthouse), Quarry Cove, and the Interpretive Center. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7024771/salmon-river-trail-742", "title": "Salmon River Trail #742", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.277914,-121.93967", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7024771", "info-text": {"description": "The popular 14-mile Salmon River Trail crosses the heart of the Salmon Huckleberry Wilderness, but most folks hike up 3-5 miles and turn around for a nice day trip. The first two miles are fairly flat followed by two steeper miles to viewpoints. It's lower elevations makes it accessible nearly year-round.  \r\n\nThe first section of trail is fairly narrow where the river has cut into the bank. The rest of the trail is wider with more distance to the river. Next you come to a side channel of the river reopened by the Forest Service to improve salmon habitat. On the far side of the channel is a large flat grove of old growth along the river shoreline. Next is the second narrow section that skirts the rocky shoreline with a deep pool of the Salmon River. Look out for namesake fish.\r\n\nStay on the trail to the first bridge at milepost one. The trail continues along the river with a view across the river of Big Horn Creek, a larger tributary coming in to the flow. Another 1/3 of a mile and you reach Rolling Riffle where there are some dispersed campsites. Just beyond the campsites is the two mile point where another bridge crosses a tributary, followed by the wilderness boundary, a trailhead board and wilderness permit box. \r\n\nAfter this, the trail begins a steady climb up and away from the river. At the three plus mile point, there is a side trail off the main trail to the right that brings you out of the forest and into a series of large moss covered rocky outcrops with viewpoints. From here, you can hear the roar and catch a glimpse of Final Falls and Frustration Falls upstream.  Continue hiking on the side loop in and out of openings. Vanishing Falls is the next waterfalls upstream. See caution below about outcropping cliffs.\r\n\nGet back onto the main trail and at milepost 4.7, you reach Goat Creek, another popular turnaround point or camping spot. For those who continue, the trail continues to climb well away from the river, passing the Kinzel Lake Trail #665 on your left and dropping and climbing out of side drainages. At about the eight-mile mark, the trail nears the river and Linney Creek Trail #499 will drop you to the river. Continue on Salmon River as it parallels the river sometimes within access to the water until you reach milepost 10.5. At this point, the much less used trail veers from the river and after another mile, it heads due north away from the river with a steady 10% grade 1.6 mile climb to the trailhead located south of Trillium", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7026657/fall-colors-make-this-trail-enjoyable-photo-by-yunkette", "ratings": {"rating": 4.4, "num_reviewers": 11}, "stats": {"dist": 13.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3466, 1598], "alt-change": [2959, 1141], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 32.0}},

It is a long drive to the trailhead and a short, steep hike down to a mountain lake. From the trailhead, the trail descends over 500 feet in 1/2 mile on a series of 17 switchbacks to Plaza Lake.  There is one campsite at the lake near the trail\u2019s end.  \r\n\nHikers can access the trail by heading east from Estacada 6.6 miles and turning left on Forest Road 4610 aka North Fork Road (across from Promontory Park). Take another immediate left onto Forest Road 4610 and travel 7.1 miles and stay left on Forest Road 4610 at the fork. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025242/plaza-trail-783", "title": "Plaza Trail #783", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.318924,-121.992024", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025242", "info-text": {"description": "Plaza Trail is one of the more rugged and isolated trails you can take on the Mt. Hood National Forest, close to Portland. Even on a summer weekend day, you are not likely to run into more than a few other hikers, if that. You can reach Plaza Trail on the north end by parking in the BLM Wildwood Day Use Area off Hwy 26 near Welches, and hiking 4 miles south on Boulder Ridge Trail #783A to its end and pick up Plaza Trail. Or you can start Plaza Trail on the south end, off of Abbot Road outside of Estacada off Hwy 224. \r\n\nIn either case, Plaza Trail follows the ridge lines of the Salmon-Huckleberry Wilderness namesake mountains. At the end of Boulder Ridge, Plaza Trail follows the ridgeline of Huckleberry Mountain as it winds across the wilderness towards Salmon Mountain and then a feature called Sheepshead Rock at the south end of the wilderness. The following description assumes you start at the south end and hike north.\r\n\nThis trail starts at Forest Road 4610 and ends at it junction with Boulder Ridge Trail #783A. From Forest Road 4610 (4,240\u2019), the trail heads north and after 50\u2019 the trail branches. The trail heading west is Old Baldy Trail #502. Head east (right) onto this trail (#783). At 1.3 miles, the trail passes Sheepshead Rock (4,460\u2019) which offers nice views to the north, west and east.    Leaving Sheepshead Rock, the trail climbs several switchbacks, descends briefly then contours a further 1.5 miles to the junction with Salmon Mountain Trail #787 (3,840\u2019). \r\n\nFrom the junction, #783 continues north, and after 2.6 miles the trail reaches the junction with Douglas Trail #781 (4,040\u2019).  Head right to stay on #783 and continue 1.6 miles to the junction with Bonanza Trail #786 (4,200\u2019). Head left to stay on #783 and the trail passes Huckleberry Mountain (4,290\u2019) in 0.1 mile. Continue heading north, going downhill 1.7 miles to the trail\u2019s end at the junction with Boulder Ridge Trail #783A. The only significant sustained grades on this trail are between the Sheepshead rock and Salmon Mountain Trail #787. There are some short, steep sections along the trail.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7027013/mt-hood-and-salmon-mountain-command-the-view-from-sheepshead-rock-on-the-plaza-t", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 9.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4612, 3721], "alt-change": [2113, 1699], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 45.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025247/salmon-mountain-trail-787", "title": "Salmon Mountain Trail #787", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.262425,-121.997674", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025247", "info-text": {"description": "Salmon Mountain Trail begins far along the Plaza Trail #783. At the junction, head southeast up the hill to the Salmon Mountain ridgeline. Bear left on the ridge into the rhododendrons. The trail roughly follows the ridge up and down before dropping to the left slightly. An old user trail continues on the ridgeline for a short distance. \r\n\nFollow the trail where it drops to the left and scramble your way through the rhododendron thickets using caution at a section with a steep, unstable sideslope. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025964/black-canyon", "title": "Black Canyon", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.706885,-120.171247", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025964", "info-text": {"description": "Black Canyon is a truly magical place that hosts a collection of wildlife, waterfalls, and bountiful plant life (some of which can't be found anywhere else in the world). The canyon is nestled into the east side of flat-topped Sutton Mountain, which rises above the surrounding foothills. The ridges and grooves of the terrain always make for an interesting experience, but the area really shines in the spring when wildflowers begin to bloom.\r\n\nThe trail starts out with a fairly mellow grade along the bottom of the gulch. However, as hikers climb higher, the grade continues to slowly steepen. There are also plenty of opportunities to press on to the summit from the assorted drainages and ridges that make up the grass-covered hills. Once on top, the surrounding panoramic views make a fantastic backdrop while you catch your breath.", "features": "Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7076555/entrance-to-upper-section-of-black-canyon-trail-approx-1-mile-from-trailhead-lot", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 3.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3411, 2047], "alt-change": [1363, 0], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7026598/row-river-trail", "title": "Row River Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.797369,-123.057866", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7026598", "info-text": {"description": "This paved rail-to-trail path runs almost 17 miles from the city of Cottage Grove to the hamlet of Culp Creek.  \r\n\nFollowing the gentle railroad grade, the trail begins in the midst of Cottage Grove. After meandering to the Mosby Creek Trailhead in the small town of Walden, the trail begins a very gradual climb up to the mountains surrounding Dorena Lake, a reservoir operated by the Army Corps of Engineers. After slicing through the forested shores of Dorena Lake, the trail returns to the countryside, passing through a few small logging communities, before finally terminating in Culp Creek.\r\n\nSeveral parking areas and drop toilet facilities are along the trail, along with picnic tables and benches for enjoying the views. Although paved, this can make for a fun summer hike away from the stress of traffic, or even a reprieve from the rainy grey of winter.  The intrepid hiker can combine this with the corresponding roads to create loops and other routes.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.8, "num_reviewers": 5}, "stats": {"dist": 16.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [964, 644], "alt-change": [466, 147], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 5.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7071151/salmon-butte-trail-791", "title": "Salmon Butte Trail #791", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.271997,-121.941179", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7071151", "info-text": {"description": "Parking for this trail is at the end of Salmon River Road about 0.7 miles past the bridge/TH for Salmon River Trail #742. The last stretch of road is dirt but you should be able to get around the potholes in any car. Many of the cars parked at the trailhead are going to be people enjoying the river, not people hiking to the top of Salmon Butte. \r\n\nThis trail has a very gentle and steady grade compared to other 3,000 foot climbs in the region. It is also very smooth - few rocks or roots - so the going is surprisingly easy. Finally, it's gets very little use considering it's proximity to Portland. \r\n\nThe clearly signed trail begins where the road is blocked off to vehicles and descends a very steep ~15 feet down to the river before almost immediately climbing back up to the closed-off road. You can just start off on the road to skip this section if you want. The road crosses South Fork Salmon River on a bridge and then quickly transitions to dirt singletrack. You'll follow the old road for about 1.5 miles but it's very grown-in and covered with wildflowers so it isn't too \"roady\" while still very clear to follow. There is some impressive old growth along the river and again after a logged area at the end of the road. \r\n\nAt about 2,750 feet and over 2.5 miles from the trailhead the fist view opens up on a clear bend in the trail with some great snack-time-rocks. You can see the South Fork valley and Sheepshead Rock. There won't be another clear viewpoint for about 2.5 more miles. At about 3.75 miles the trail appears to head out into a clearing because so many people miss the first true switchback here. There are only a few more switchbacks as the slope of Salmon Butte is gradual enough to not need many. \r\n\nFinally, at about 5 miles the trail curves around the ridge of Salmon Butte, enters tons of rhododendrons, and a few views to Hood briefly open up. The last mile of the trail is the loveliest thanks to the rhododendrons and other wildflowers. 3/4 of a mile from the summit the trail merges with an old road that bends around to the south side of Salmon Butte before the final ascent push. \r\n\nFrom the top you can expect to see St. Helens, Mount Rainier, Mount Adams, Mount Hood, Mount Jefferson, and a glimpse of the Three Sisters. It's large enough for a few groups to hang out.", "features": "Fishing \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7071102/hood-dominates-the-vista", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 5.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4678, 1679], "alt-change": [3080, 136], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 40.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7100368/pats-cabin-trail", "title": "Pat's Cabin Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.698636,-120.285018", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7100368", "info-text": {"description": "Head to the Painted Hills Unit of the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument along Burnt Ranch Road. When you reach a junction at the end of the paved road, instead of turning left (west) towards the National Monument continue straight north for approx. 3 miles. If you see a road to the right (east) with a BLM sign for \"Priest Hole Rec. Site\" you've gone about 200 feet too far. \r\n\nThe trailhead is at a large flat grassy area west of the road with plenty of camping area (no trees though) or on the east side of the road near a large cattle loading pen. The trail starts at the southern end of the grassy area. Crossing Bridge Creek (which can be high in spring, though some boards were put across it to help in the crossing) you continue in a southern direction for a couple hundred feet. \r\n\nIf you run into fencing for a ranch turn west and you should come upon the old jeep road which forms the basic trail. You start out in relatively treeless grassland heading up the canyon. The higher you go the more trees. Pat's cabin is located on a saddle at around 3,000 ft elevation. If you have a GPS with you (and you should) when the jeep road reaches this elevation the saddle will be to your left (south) and the cabin is visible from the saddle to the west. \r\n\nThe trail is a mix of sometimes the old jeep trail, sometimes in the wash of Pat's Cabin Canyon and sometimes human/game trails alongside the wash. There is not a set trail, choose your own best route up the canyon. \r\n\nIn addition to carrying a GPS, I highly recommend the USGS topo map \"Painted Hills\" (the 1968 version is actually better than the 2020 version since it shows the old jeep road and a well near where the cabin is located). Also, looking for footprints can help you stay in the right canyon.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7077592/view-east-towards-sutton-mountain-from-knoll-near-pats-cabin-4-2-2021", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 4.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3069, 1730], "alt-change": [1339, 12], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7100521/black-canyon-to-sutton-mountain", "title": "Black Canyon to Sutton Mountain", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.686956,-120.194477", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7100521", "info-text": {"description": "A route from Black Canyon to the plateau that makes up much of Sutton Mountain. Once on the plateau you get nice views of the surrounding area including Sutton Mountain's summit (southeast of the route end).\r\n\nFollow the Black Canyon trail approximately 2.5 miles from the trailhead. A canyon will open up to the south which you can follow all the way up to the Sutton Mountain plateau. The walls of the canyon are grassy and steep in places, but not high enough to be dangerous (take extra care if the ground is muddy). \r\n\nThe canyon bottom is not fit for walking/running due to lots of brush and boulders. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031804/bandersnatch", "title": "Bandersnatch", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.179549,-122.709194", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031804", "info-text": {"description": "Bandersnatch is probably the most popular forest lands trail in the Ashland watershed. It's a pedestrian-equestrian trail that starts just off the Waterline Trail near Lithia Park and climbs steeply at times to reach its summit where it crosses the Alice in Wonderland Trail. It then descends on the east side of Alice to connect with JubJub and then joins FS Road 2060. There is a picnic bench with views of Mt Ashland about a half mile up from the trailhead before the trail crosses the BTI mountain bike trail. There are good views of the mountains as well as the Rogue valley. \r\n\nBears, deer, and cougars have been spotted on or near this trail. This trail is usually below the snow zone in the winter and continues to get frequent use all year-round.\r\n\n Poison oak thrives in and around this trail. Several artworks appear along the bottom of the trail near Waterline.\r\n\nOther Trail Connections About two-thirds up the trail on the right is the Snark Trail which will loop back down to the Waterline Trail. Just above this intersection is the Red Queen trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031805/waterline-trail", "title": "Waterline Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.181239,-122.716012", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031805", "info-text": {"description": "Waterline starts just above Lithia Park, near a large parking area on Glenview St., and is a gentle climb at first, followed by a very steep, intense grade, after which it is flat for almost a half mile. In this section, the trail parallels Ashland Creek. \r\n\nNear the trailhead, it is multi-use with hikers, runners, bikers and equestrians (rarely). The few equestrians must turn on Bandersnatch, where pedestrians have the option of continuing on to the Waterline Trail and eventually to the Snark Trail. \r\n\nVirtually all mountain bike traffic is downhill on Waterline coming from BTI and Jabberwocky, however, the occasional cross-country cyclist may hike up Waterline and Snark. Be aware that mountain bikers have a hard time stopping quickly on the one steep hill so those on foot should be alert. Pedestrians and runners should stay to the right on the trail going up and and on the left going down. \r\n\nThere is poison oak along parts of this trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031806/snark-trail", "title": "Snark Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.17375,-122.713362", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031806", "info-text": {"description": "Snark is a relatively unknown gem in the lower Ashland trail system connecting Waterline Trail to Bandersnatch and with quick access to Red Queen. On the low end, it features some quiet, shaded forest areas and then climbs, often steeply, up to some sunny slopes to Bandersnatch. \r\n\nThis trail is a great alternative to the lower part of Bandersnatch and has very little traffic. Bikers seem to try this early in the morning and are seldom seen beyond that. Steep sections may be daunting for some hikers in the dry time of year because of the ball bearing like nature of the decomposed granite surface. \r\n\nThis trail is more primitive--narrower and steeper--than most in the area and that is some of its appeal. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7043219/vineyard-loop", "title": "Vineyard Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.712517,-119.199045", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7043219", "info-text": {"description": "Hop over the road from the parking area and take a right. A short climb has you up on the side and hiking easily for a bit. A gentle climb puts you on the canyon rim at the 1.1 mile mark. There are two gates to go through. Make a right and don't fall off! At the 1.75 mile point you'll start to drop back down and after a set of switchbacks, you'll be at the low point of the trail. Now you get to hike up an old ditch all the way to the gravel road. To get back, join the main road briefly for a climb and drop back down to the parking area.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 2.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [799, 670], "alt-change": [214, 184], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 12.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031825/lewis-loops-gyre", "title": "Lewis Loops: Gyre", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.159561,-122.700418", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031825", "info-text": {"description": "Lewis Loops, built in 2016, is a figure-eight trail comprised of this larger Gyre loop and smaller Lewis Loops: Gimble trail.\r\n\nThe Gyre loop is closer to the Caterpillar Trail, from which Lewis Loops starts. Proceeding clockwise on Gyre, one enjoys a steady climb with great eastern exposure and views of Ashland and eventually Mt McLoughlin to the north. You pass by a large, still living Ponderosa that was struck by lightning--notice the vertical \"claw-like\" marks. This is in contrast to actual bear claw marks on madrones in the area (and on the Lewis Loops: Gimble trail). \r\n\nYou continue up to a ridge on an old fire break, converted into a trail (formerly called Pete's Punisher) to a particularly noteworthy viewpoint where one can see Mt. Ashland to the south and Mt. McLoughlin to the north. Just below you to the south is the Research Natural Area, about 1600 acres of Ponderosa pine, Douglas fir, sugar pine, white fir and Pacific madrone. Much of this is visible along this trail. Wildflowers abound: mountain lupine thrives here. \r\n\nAfter descending Gyre, still in the clockwise direction, you reach the intersection with Lewis Loops: Gimble. Gimble is mostly an out-and-back along a ridge but features a short loop at the low end with some different views of the watershed and Rogue Valley. Look for the bear claw marks on one of the madrones (the bears like the berries). Remember, when you descend Gimble, the only way back is to return the way you came--back to Gyre and Caterpillar Trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7032558/mt-ashland-from-lewis-loops-gyre-robert-nicholson-photo", "ratings": {"rating": 4.8, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 1.4, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [3851, 3530], "alt-change": [390, 379], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 44.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7032874/stahlman-point-trail-3449", "title": "Stahlman Point Trail #3449", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.706853,-122.160997", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7032874", "info-text": {"description": "Start at the Stahlman Point trailhead on the south side of Detroit Lake. The trailhead lies right between Shady Cove and the South Shore Campgrounds on the lake. You'll have to hike this as an out-and-back; there are no roads or alternative ways to the summit. \r\n\nFrom the start, the trail meanders through second growth Douglas Fir forest complete with the usual Oregon understory of Oregon Grape, Salal, and Sword Fern. The trail is steep, but never relentless. Short, steep sections give way to well-timed, leg-resting reprieves. \r\n\nAbout halfway up the trail, you'll begin to catch views of Detroit Lake, Dome Rock, and French Creek Ridge through the forest. At 2,500', the trail turns southeast and enters a section of old-growth Douglas Fir forest. Shortly after ducking under an ancient, downed forest giant that hangs above the trail, you'll pass over an intermittent creek and resume climbing. \r\n\nAfter the creek, the steepness levels off a bit and makes for an enjoyable climb as the views get better and better through the forest. Two more switchbacks and you'll be on top of Stahlman Point enjoying the views. The Point used to be a fire lookout for obvious reasons. \r\n\nFrom the summit, soak in the 360-degree views of Detroit Lake, Coffin Mountain, French Creek Ridge, the North Santiam River, and, finally, Mt. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7093223/lower-wonder-trail", "title": "Lower Wonder Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.17835,-122.718213", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7093223", "info-text": {"description": "This recently completed (April 2020) portion of the Ashland Trails Project connects the Fairy Ponds Trailhead with the Wonder Trail near Forest Road 2060. There are brief views of Grizzly Peak, the City of Ashland, and Mt Ashland from the trail. You can also see the tip of Mount McLoughlin if you look closely. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7032727/high-lakes-trail-6200", "title": "High Lakes Trail #6200", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.394898,-122.316864", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7032727", "info-text": {"description": "The High Lakes Trail, which is wide and smooth and surfaced with a fine crushed rock, is a delightful path through the woods, popular with hikers looking for a casual jaunt. The trail also can be combined with the more difficult Brown Mountain Loop.\r\n\nEasily hikeed in either direction or as an out-and-back, here is a description from the western trailhead:\r\nFrom the Fish Lake Resort access road, The High Lakes Trail ascends gradually for a mile, then descends slightly and passes the Brown Mountain Trail coming in from the right. More gentle climbing resumes for another couple miles until the high point is reached. Along the way, the trail has been painstakingly engineered through some impressive boulder fields of the Brown Mountain lava flows. \r\n\nAfter a mile of gradual descent and another mile of level traversing through old growth timber, there is a junction where the Brown Mountain Trail turns off to the south at a crossing of Forest Road #3640. \r\n\nContinuing with little elevation change, the High Lakes Trail skirts the north end of Lake of the Woods and passes a picnic/swimming area on the NE corner of the lake. From there, the level trail continues for nearly two miles as it hugs the edge of boggy meadow to reach the Great Meadow Trailhead.\r\n\nCamping, cabins, boat rentals, and cafe (think beer) are available at Fish Lake Resort near the western end of the trail. A similar, but larger scale operation is located just south of the eastern terminus of the trail, at Lake of the Woods Resort.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7056970/high-lakes-trail-6200brown-mt-loop", "ratings": {"rating": 3.8, "num_reviewers": 5}, "stats": {"dist": 9.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5193, 4672], "alt-change": [671, 388], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034775/brown-mountain-trail-1005", "title": "Brown Mountain Trail #1005", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.377388,-122.232314", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034775", "info-text": {"description": "The Brown Mountain Trail #1005 is most commonly traveled from east to west, or clockwise when combined with the High Lakes Trail #6200 to make a loop. Starting on the west side of Lake of the Woods, the #1005 (#3724) cross Forest Road (FR) 3601 and then FR 3640 (limited parking), but you can also reach it from the nearby High Lakes Trail Trailhead via the High Lakes Trail Tie #6200B. From either trailhead, the Brown Mountain Trail heads south for a gradual singletrack ascent of 700 feet over 2.5 miles through big trees brings you to the trail's high point at 5700'. From here there is a long gradual descent, through huckleberry bushes which can at times partially hide some roots and rocks in the path. \r\n\nThe Pacific Crest Trail is crossed after 2 miles of this descent, then a small un-named doubletrack, then the Blue Lick Road (FR 3705-500,  gravel) is met at about 6 miles from the trailhead. Go left (north), cross the creek, then look left (west) to pick up the singletrack again. \r\n\nThe next mile and a half follows the north side of the creek, and there are some rocky sections to negotiate before reaching the paved one-lane Brown Mountain Road (FR 3705) and South Brown Mountain Trailhead. Cross this road and continue on singletrack for another half mile before it merges with a 4WD doubletrack (FR 3705-375) which, after another mile and a half, brings you back around to the Brown Mountain Road near the South Fork of Little Butte Creek.\r\n\nAfter crossing this creek, turn right on Forest Road 350 (sign for Brown Mtn Trail), and follow this for 0.1 mile before turning left on to a signed singletrack again.\r\n\nThis next section of singletrack is spectacular as it winds between and through lava fields, gaining a couple hundred feet as it climbs up over the west side of Brown Mountain. In a little more than two miles, another doubletrack is reached.\r\n\nThis one is FR 900 (called the \"Pillette Road\") and is also the \"Lollipop Loop\"  nordic ski trail. Follow FR 900 straight north, past a gate closing the road, to the West Brown Mountain Trailhead at 4730', 13.8 miles from where you started.\r\n\nAt this point, it is possible to continue straight ahead on FR 900 to where the High Lakes Trail crosses it, then go left to Fish Lake resort for a beer. However, to complete the Brown Mountain Trail, continue up the final 3/4 mile section of trail, which is rough in places, to meet the High Lakes Trail #6200.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7039199/mount-mcloughlin-from-the-west-side-of-brown-mountain", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 14.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5656, 4682], "alt-change": [1182, 1293], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7041729/pct-highway-140-to-highway-138-near-cascade-crest", "title": "PCT: Highway 140 to Highway 138 (near Cascade Crest)", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.395866,-122.29146", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7041729", "info-text": {"description": "The Sky Lakes Wilderness is a long, skinny expanse of 113,590 acres, stretching along the crest of the Cascades from Crater Lake on the north nearly to Highway 140 on the south, the highway that runs between Medford and Klamath Falls. The west side of the wilderness is in the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest, the east side in the Fremont-Winema National Forest.  It's pretty much everyone's favorite wild place in the Southern Oregon Cascades.  \r\n\nThis section of the Pacific Crest Trail runs north to south through the Sky Lakes, starting at Highway 140 in the south, crosses a number of trails along the way that allow access to various lakes or can be used to form hiking or backpacking loops, then crosses Crater Lake National Park, and ends at Highway 138 in the north. The biggest downside to the Sky Lakes are the thirsty hoards of mosquitos that infest the area from late-June to early-September.\r\n\nNote that the main PCT through the Park does not come close to Crater Lake\u2014it's basically a path through a forest. This is fine if you're a thru hiker needing to make miles but, if you want to see the lake, then use the PCT Alternate South and PCT Alternate North trails to get a wonderful big view of the lake from the West Rim.", "features": "Commonly Backpacked \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7010370/union-peak-as-seen-from-the-fork-between-the-pct-and-union-peak-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 76.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [7351, 4976], "alt-change": [8113, 7167], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 20.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005287/burma-road", "title": "Burma Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.374378,-121.137277", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005287", "info-text": {"description": "The beginning of the trail is at the end of Wolf Tree Trail at the intersection with Homestead Trail.  \r\n\nA climbing access trail for Student Wall splits off to the right in about a third of a mile.  This trail is singletrack for a while until you reach an irrigation canal.  The canal drops into an underground culvert.  Careful with your animals around this area. Several dogs have fallen into the canal and been sucked into the culvert, it is about a mile before they pop out.  \r\n\nAfter the canal, you join an old BLM road that is cut into the side of the hill.  It is visible from the parking lot at Smith Rock State Park.  At the switchback, there is a climbing access trail that will take you to Koala Rock and the rest of the Marsupial Rock formation.  You'll climb about 900 feet in this section.  As you ascend this section, you can look back over Smith Rock State Park and observe the Three Sisters, Mt. Jefferson, and on good days, Mt. Hood. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005288/summit-trail", "title": "Summit Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.376484,-121.127117", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005288", "info-text": {"description": "The Summit Trail is the northern-most section of the Smith Rock State Park Summit Loop Trail, and where the Smith Rock State Park Summit Loop Trail gets its name. \r\n\nFrom the top of Burma Road you'll join several switchbacks that drop you in altitude.  When the trail begins to straighten out you'll be at the top of the Monument Ridge.  It is very easy to sneak over to the edge for some breathtaking views of the valley.  Along the Summit Trail, there is a small viewpoint spur that takes you to another cliff edge.  Plenty of open \"High Desert\" country to look at.  \r\n\nThis section of the trail is pretty smooth and easy to walk, ride, or hike on.  The slope is not as steep as the Burma Road. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005289/river-trail", "title": "River Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.372689,-121.145191", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005289", "info-text": {"description": "After descending into the canyon on the Chute Trail you'll cross the river and turn left.  This very popular trail is flat and fairly wide.  It is used as a connector trail for bicyclists, and is a main access trail to the most popular climbing area in the park.\r\n\nAs you start down River Trail you can observe the Picnic Wall, an area that has mostly advanced climbs.  Within the first 1/4 mile you'll pass under a Rhyolite intrusion to the welded tuft rock.  This striking red rock if very rough looking in a beautiful way.  On your left will be the Crooked River.  \r\n\nAs you continue down the trail it is easy to spot the rock climbers. There are many climbing access trails that break off to the right.  They are more narrow but will eventually lead you back down to the River Trail.  Shortly you'll pass the last bathroom, it's actually a compost vault toilet.  As you pass the Morning Glory Rock Formation you'll spot a rock that looks like a Snoopy Head, this is Asterisk Pass.  This trail is only recommended for experienced rock climbers as it is about 50 feet on a very narrow ledge with no protection.  \r\n\nJust past Asterisk Pass you begin to see the actual Smith Rock Group.  These rocks are very rugged.  The River Trail now bends around to the left.  You'll soon come to a house-sized boulder in the river, if you look across the river you'll see an ancient pine tree.  This tree has been the home of nesting Bald Eagles for the last 3 years.  Past the boulder, you'll reach the Southern Tip of Smith Rock.  There are several undercuts to the cliff where you can seek shade for a summer lunch or duck under to dodge the rare rain shower.  \r\n\nAs the trail turns north it narrows somewhat and begins to have small dips to go around ancient pine trees.  There are several access points along here so you can take a quick dip in the river to cool off in the summer.  As you pass the junction for the Mesa Verde Trail you'll be able to see the Monkey Face Spiral.  This is where most people split off to continue the Mesa Verde/Misery Ridge Loop. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005882/homestead-trail", "title": "Homestead Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.370519,-121.135058", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005882", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts off in the north point parking lot. It cuts through several small rock outcroppings and begin down.  There is the occasional loose pebble that will roll if you are not careful. This is a climbers trail, if you take it you well soon be boulder hopping to the base of the cliff.  \r\n\nContinuing down the switchbacks you'll get a good view of the river.  At the bottom of the switchbacks is an intersection.  Straight or slightly right will take you to the river and the horse crossing.  \r\n\nThe main trail turns left.  You'll pass an ancient pine tree with a huge bent limb.  This is a great area for photo ops.  The trail flattens out along the river and is very easy going. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005966/misery-ridge", "title": "Misery Ridge", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.368117,-121.139262", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005966", "info-text": {"description": "From the bridge, go straight and start up the first set of switchbacks. There are several user trails in this area taking you to different overlooks.  \r\n\nAs you continue up and over the summit, you'll be able to see the mountains to the west. There is a memorial bench that provides a convenient resting place while enjoying the vistas.  As you start down you'll be very close to Monkey Face Pinnacle.  The switchbacks will begin again, at first frequent, then as you progress down further apart.  Watch for a boulder with a hole in it, climb in, now look out the window.  This is a great place for pictures.  \r\n\nUse caution on this section. The steepness of the trail combined with the loose pebbles can make footing very difficult. Once at the top of the ridge at the east end, things get fairly technical starting with a very rocky 180-degree turn around the edge of the ridge.\r\n\nNext, you\u2019ll hit a series of back-to-back, steep rocky climbs that will test your calf strength. Eventually, the trail levels off and opens up to a few nice views of the Cascade Range. \r\n\nThe trail soon spits out onto a fairly long fire road climb which takes you up to the Swede Shelter. The rich forests provide ample shade that combines with the elevation to makes for a great cooler summer outing. \r\n\nAs you hike, look for birds, wildlife, fish, sunken stumps, great lake views, and a dam and spillway (you might even discover an unauthorized rope swing). {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7033931/upper-sandy-river-trail", "title": "Upper Sandy River Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.401636,-122.269702", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7033931", "info-text": {"description": "The Upper Sandy River Trail is an old rocky logging road that heads from the end of Marcy Street down towards the Sandy River. The first part of the trail heads down the hill with a view on your left, and an old slide after that. The road takes a sharp left turn at the bottom of the hill. At this point, the Jim Slagle Loop Trail is on your left and is an actual designed trail instead of the logging road. If you decide to stay on the logging road, continue north as the trail/road travels through a 20-year-old logged-over area. There are lots of hardwoods, young Douglas fir, and cedars. You pass an old failed beaver pond where a culvert crosses under the road. When you come to a large opening (old log landing), the Sandy River Midway Trail is on your left and connects back to the Jim Slagle Loop Trail.  \r\n\nContinue on the old logging road as it curves and drops a bit steeper down the hill. You come to a flat area where the Jim Slagle Loop Trail intersects. If you want to skip the trip down to the river, you can make a loop and return on the Jim Slagle Loop Trail. Otherwise, you can continue on the Lower Sandy River Trail to the river.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7034536/this-is-the-largest-tree-around-for-miles-the-western-red-cedar-has-a-bee-hive-w", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 0.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [808, 448], "alt-change": [0, 360], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 32.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7033935/lower-sandy-river-trail", "title": "Lower Sandy River Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.407905,-122.268076", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7033935", "info-text": {"description": "The Lower Sandy River Trail drops to the shoreline of the Sandy River where Cedar Creek flows into the main channel.  The trail starts at the intersection with the Upper Sandy River Trail (an old logging road) and the Jim Slagle Loop Trail (constructed in 2015). Before the trail drops to the river, there is a short spur to a viewpoint that shows a small waterfall and the Sandy River beyond. Please do not cut switchbacks that descend to the river as this trail is difficult to maintain and easily eroded. Cutting switchbacks channels the rainfall into the switchbacks and erodes the entire hillside, so stay on the path!  \r\n\nOnce you reach the Sandy River, you may see some fishermen and women. Cedar Creek flows into the main channel just upstream. There is a fish hatchery further up Cedar Creek, which makes this confluence a popular destination for returning spawning salmon and folks fishing and fish-watching in the fall. A separate trail comes down to this point from the fish hatchery. The trail peters out at the river, but a fishing trail leads downstream. Be careful, as these trails are not designed or maintained and can be unstable and adjacent to fast-moving water. The ice cold Sandy River makes an \"oxbow\" (u shaped) turn just downstream. This causes fast, changing currents as well as large log debris jams.  \r\n\nUnfortunately, some fishermen leave fishing line, hooks, beer bottles, and trash. Pack a trash bag to pack some out, and you can call yourself and your kids a Sandy River Eco-Helper! Please keep your dogs on a leash and give some clearance to fishermen trying to cast a line.  \r\n\nThis trail is a good place to come see salmon spawning in the fall in Cedar Creek. After a good rain that brings the creek levels up, the salmon can be easily seen laying eggs in redds, or fighting each other to fertilize the eggs. There are also some spent dead salmon on the river bank that can attract bears and other wildlife, so keep an eye out and do not let your dog get anywhere near the carcasses if you don't want an emergency veterinarian trip.\r\n\nOnce you head back up the trail, I recommend taking the Jim Slagle Loop Trail to return. It is amazing to have such a gem of a destination so close to Sandy. For a famous photo op to memorialize your trip, head a half mile down Bluff Road to take your picture at the Jonsrud Viewpoint where you can see your Sandy River destination, Mt. Hood, Mt. Adams, the Bull Run Watershed, and the Devil's Backbone, which is part of the Oregon Trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7034536/this-is-the-largest-tree-around-for-miles-the-western-red-cedar-has-a-bee-hive-w", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [442, 372], "alt-change": [1, 70], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 15.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7033940/jim-slagle-loop-trail", "title": "Jim Slagle Loop Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.401447,-122.266109", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7033940", "info-text": {"description": "The Jim Slagle Loop Trail is a great way to access the Sandy River. One of Sandy's secret gems, this trail is much less steep or rocky than the Upper Sandy River Trail, which is an old logging road. It was designed by a famous Northwest trail designer (and local Sandy resident!) Jim Slagle. This was the last trail he designed before his retirement after 40+ years of trail design including Sandy's other gem, Tickle Creek Trail and most of the trails in the Mt. St. Helens Monument. The local youth corps AntFarm worked with local trail builder Gene Tilgner to construct the trail in 2015.\r\n\nThe trail starts where the Upper Sandy River Trail descends and takes a sharp left (north). Take a sharper left and head northwest onto the trail. The first section of trail was an older section of trail that was repaired. There is a large nurse stump with a tree growing out of it and then a small creek. Continue north and cross over a large culvert that is another small tributary to the Sandy River. The trail then heads east and, at a large cedar snag, there is an intersection. The Jim Slagle Loop turns to the left, and going straight ahead is the short Sandy River Midway Trail that takes you back to the logging road (Upper Sandy River Trail). From here, turn left (north). The trail crosses another small creek before coming out to a viewpoint over the river. Along this section of trail is a very large bigleaf maple tree that shades a handy snack or lunch stop.\r\n\nThe trail then gets into thicker cedar forests with a steep side slope. Trailside ferns and \"pistol-butted\" trees grow out of the slopes demonstrating the occasional landslides and loose soil. The trail drops down into an open wet area and crosses a boardwalk/bridge made from parts of the old fallen cedar tree next to the trail. There is private land adjacent to this spot, so please stay on the trail.\r\n\nAcross the boardwalk, the trail takes a sharp right and heads east. You then come to a dense second-growth western red cedar thicket located above the audible Sandy River. The trail then leads you to the largest tree (western red cedar) around, which makes a great photo op! Continue to its end at the intersection with the Upper and Lower Sandy River Trail.  Take a left to head to the river or a right to head back up toward town. I recommend the river and returning on the Jim Slagle Loop the way you came. Shorter loops or figure-eights can be made with the Sandy River and Midway Trails.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7034536/this-is-the-largest-tree-around-for-miles-the-western-red-cedar-has-a-bee-hive-w", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [704, 444], "alt-change": [15, 275], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035309/phillips-lake-south-shore-trail", "title": "Phillips Lake South Shore Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.677509,-118.090263", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035309", "info-text": {"description": "The Phillips Lake South Shoreline trail begins near the Southwest Shore Campground and ends near the south side of Mason Dam.\r\n\nThe trail traverses the southerly banks of the reservoir through grasslands and young ponderosa pine trees. It is a scenic trail and offers outstanding views of the lake and the Elkhorn Mountains. The numerous coves and inlets make it easy to see wildlife along the hike. There are only short uphills on this trail and overall it is very easy. There is some exposure along the way peppering in a little excitement. \r\n\nThis trail can be hikeed with the Phillips Lake North Shore Trail to make a large loop. You'll just need to hike on Hudspeth Lane to connect the two trails at the west end and cross the dam at the east end.\r\n\nYou can also turn onto the Rim Rock Trail to get some extra miles.", "features": "Lake \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 6.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4101, 4074], "alt-change": [107, 105], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},

The trail is generally well marked. \r\n\nWithin the first 1/2 mile, the Hart-Tish Campground is passed. Here, when in doubt, follow campground trails that follow the contour close to the lake. This is in the vicinity of the Watkins Campground. Go right, uphill, for a short-cut up to the campground, otherwise the lakeside route will bring you to the same point after one switchback.\r\n\nThis trail ends here at Watkins CG.
