{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7072758/little-north-santiam-trail-3338", "title": "Little North Santiam Trail #3338", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.833746,-122.350784", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7072758", "info-text": {"description": "This trail has parking at both ends so it can be done in either direction or as a short shuttle. Parking is limited at both ends. The dirt roads leading to either side should be passable by any vehicle. This version is mapped from west to east. \r\n\nFrom the west end of the trail you'll set off through a plantation before the trail takes a quick switchback to the left/north. Enough people have missed this turn that there is a very well-worn trail leading 50 feet or so to a rock where it obviously ends. You'll cross a bridge over a small creek and a second bridge over a larger creek before Santiam River comes into view. The next section of the trail has great views of the river and impressive rapids. \r\n\nYou'll soon come to another creek crossing that lacks a bridge and can be precarious when the water is high. Triple Falls is only a short distance after the creek - a suitable reward. Triple Falls is very impressive with high water, but obscured by trees. There's a great campsite here too. \r\n\nAfter Triple Falls the trail leaves the river and climbs over 400 feet. There are two good viewpoints near the top of this ascent from which you can see Henline Mountain and Santiam River far below. The trail then descends about 400 feet and returns to the edge of Santiam River. You'll cross two more creeks: one with large logs that make crossing easy and the other small enough to not cause problems. \r\n\nThe next feature is Three Pools, a very popular set of swimming holes. Three Pools Day Use Area is across the river offering much easier access than this trail (and hence it can be quite crowded in summer). \r\n\nThe trail continues to follow Santiam River the remaining ~one mile to the east trailhead without any significant elevation changes and only one more notable creek crossing.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7066465/henline-mountain-from-a-view-point-near-the-highest-part-of-the-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 4.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1783, 1195], "alt-change": [871, 665], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 42.0}},

The trail is very wide, paved, and flat, so it is easy going. \r\n\nThe trail begins at the main parking area and heads north to be near the edge of the Columbia River. Multiple access trails will take you down to the \"beach\" along the river, but swimming is prohibited due to the unpredictable currents and multiple fatalities over the years. You'll come to Kelly's Point at the confluence of the Willamette and Columbia Rivers. Then the trail heads south along the Willamette, offering more \"beach\" access. Finally, it turns east and dead-ends along the Columbia Slough. \r\n\nThere are multiple meadows and picnic areas along this trail. There are also a number of trails you can take back to the park road/parking areas to shorten the route or make loops. \r\n\nNote: dogs are supposed to be leashed, but nearly every dog we saw was off leash and well behaved.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7060933/kelly-point-park", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [43, 27], "alt-change": [15, 27], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7020849/boulder-ridge-trail-783a", "title": "Boulder Ridge Trail #783A", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.350473,-121.991898", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7020849", "info-text": {"description": "Boulder Ridge Trail begins in BLM's Wildwood Recreation Site. Visitors must have a day use pass to park at the site. Proceed past the entrance booth for .5 miles and turn into the first parking area on your left. Once parked, head over the large bridge over Salmon River towards the wetlands trails. Cross over the bridge and pass by the trail fork on your left. Going straight puts you on a loop with the Wetlands Trail on your left and the Foot Trail on your right. Take either one and they both lead to the turnoff for the Boulder Ridge Trail which then crosses a footbridge over Sixes Creek. \r\n\nOnce on the Boulder Ridge Trail, it begins a heart pumping climb up one of many switchbacks, then dipping into  another drainage, crossing a couple of creeks and coming to a viewpoint. There was significant blow down on this trail that has been recently cleared. Continue climbing, and recross one of the creeks higher on the hill and soon the trail turns into an old logging road bed. \r\n\nFollow the old road bed for awhile, and then the trail starts a long, steady climb to the ridge top. There is a short user trail on your left that takes you out to a viewpoint of Mt. Hood. The trail skirts just below the ridge line of Huckleberry Mountain before finally topping out and heading east towards the true summit of Huckleberry Mountain and meeting up with the Plaza Trail #783 that continues on the Huckleberry Mountain ridge top.\r\n\nBoulder Ridge is a fairly steep trail and there are sections that are narrow with drop offs. The blowdown along the trail has been cut out, but more blow down is possible and that affects trail tread width. For the best views, visitors should continue on past the junction with Plaza Trail #783 to the open areas on the ridgetop. This trail receives relatively little use and those who make it to the top of Huckleberry Mountain are rewarded with awesome views of Mt. Hood, Mt. Adams, Lolo Pass, Hunchback Mountain and the Salmon-Huckleberry Wilderness.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7022546/mt-hood-from-boulder-ridge-trail-on-huckleberry-mt-photo-by-david-brown", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 4.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3796, 1183], "alt-change": [2613, 22], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 44.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7079804/lower-silver-falls-trail", "title": "Lower Silver Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.482389,-123.932628", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7079804", "info-text": {"description": "From the parking area go left (northwest) to find the start of the Silver Falls Trail marked with an informative plaque. From here, a short, nearly flat trail climbs easily to the base of Silver Falls, where you can look up at where the water spills over the uniquely rounded top of the falls. The trail becomes rockier and more uneven at the base of the falls. If you want to scramble higher for a closer look at the falls or for photography, be careful as boulders can be quite slippery when wet (spray or rain).", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7085235/video-review-of-the-golden-and-silver-falls-natural-area-trails-with-footage-of-", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [487, 379], "alt-change": [108, 2], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 10.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7079805/upper-silver-and-golden-falls-trail", "title": "Upper Silver and Golden Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.482285,-123.932637", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7079805", "info-text": {"description": "From the parking area, cross the creek as through you were going to the Lower Golden Falls Trail but take the left fork in the trail at the base of a large tree. This is the start of a longer trail that climbs gently uphill to the top of Golden Falls. About 0.3 miles up this trail, there is a side trail to the east side of the base of Silver Falls (here, again, watch your footing on any wet, slippery rocks at the base of the falls). From this junction, the main trail continues uphill beneath towering moss-covered boulders and sheer cliff faces to views of the top of Golden Falls. The last few hundred feet of this trail is along a long-abandoned road that was blasted out of the cliffs, leaving a 200-foot drop on one side. Be very careful if you're tempted to look over the edge.\r\n\nThe Lower Silver Falls Trail and this trail from the side trail junction to the top of Golden Falls and beyond, was originally a freight road built by a group of homesteaders in 1901. A now long gone wooden bridge built beneath Silver Falls connected these two pieces of the road, which remained in operation until 1958.", "features": "Views \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7085235/video-review-of-the-golden-and-silver-falls-natural-area-trails-with-footage-of-", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [668, 339], "alt-change": [402, 73], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 19.0}},

This is the only trail in the 1000 acre dog park that requires dogs to be kept on a leash both on the trail and within 100 feet of it. This rule is rarely followed, however. Most of this trail passes through open meadows before it enters woods and swampy areas for the last third. There are a number of spots where you can spot the Sandy River and a few other informal trails leading to it. The trail ends at an elevated bird blind that is \"comprised of black locust slats, list[ing] all the species encountered by Lewis and Clark during the 1804-1806 Corps of Discovery expedition\" per the USDA FS website. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7053949/enchanted-forest-trail", "title": "Enchanted Forest Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.302369,-123.189936", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7053949", "info-text": {"description": "The trail is maintained by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and is accessible year round. The Enchanted Forest Trail starts from a very small parking area at the end of Slagle Creek Road in the Applegate Valley, about 20 miles west of Medford, Oregon. From the trailhead, the trail (actually an old road here) passes a large meadow and traverses a slope thick with buckbrush and twisted oaks before entering the creek drainage. An old car body signals the end of the old road and the start of a singletrack trail up the drainage under a tall forest canopy.\r\n\nAt 0.5 miles from the trailhead, you pass a signed junction with the Felton Memorial Trail, a 1.5 mile long trail that leads to a memorial for three men who perished when their helicopter crashed near the terminus of the trail. The Enchanted Forest Trail continues up the drainage until, at 1.6 miles from the trailhead, it turns sharply west and climbs to the ridgecrest, where it ends at a private property boundary. A short stroll southwest along the ridge will provide a limited view of the Applegate Valley. It is possible to continue upslope from here on an old road but doing so would cause you to trespass on private land. Best to turn around here and enjoy another pass through the forest.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7050459/passing-through-the-meadow", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 1.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2784, 1776], "alt-change": [1009, 51], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 32.0}},

Parking is available at the end of a short gravel access road off of Buena Vista Road. If driving north on Buena Vista Road, turn right onto the access road immediately before crossing the Luckiamute River. \r\n\nFrom the parking area, hike past the gate and follow a short connector trail to the start of the main loop, where there is an informational sign with maps and guidelines. Hiking counterclockwise, head through a restored riparian gallery forest filled with cottonwood, ash, and oak along a short bluff above the Willamette River. Several short spur trails provide scenic views of the river. \r\n\nAt 1.2 miles, the trail bends southwest, turning into a wide doubletrack bordering a field\u2014this stretch can get hot in summer. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7096371/alder-creek-trail", "title": "Alder Creek Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.710661,-123.907879", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7096371", "info-text": {"description": "Park on the side of the road and go around the gate, which has a clear footpath through the gap. The gate is meant to prevent vehicle traffic, as this trail is open to the public.\r\n\nHike east along the closed road, which is wide and flat. The road is grassy in the middle and shaded by alders. It's a pleasant and easy hike that is used mainly by locals hiking their dogs and exploring with children, sometimes on bikes. To the north is the Alder Creek Nature Preserve. Keep dogs on the leash to prevent them from disturbing wildlife in the nature preserve. \r\n\nTo the south is the Nehalem Bay estuary, which harbors plenty of birds and wildlife. The road is bordered by blackberry bushes in many places, which ripen in August and can be picked by anyone with the will to brave the thorns.\r\n\nThe road continues across a sturdy bridge with railings that crosses over a tributary creek to the bay, and there is an opportunity to turn towards the estuary and take a longer loop via Elk Run Trail, which follows the edge of the estuary. Continue past the intersection and straight on until you reach the utility station. From here you can return to the car by the same route. \r\n\nYou may see others coming down the road from the utility station, as the Elk Run Trail Loop connects just on the other side. This longer loop is very popular with locals.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7072897/the-trail-passes-under-sitka-spruce-and-into-a-sunny-area-ahead", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [16, 11], "alt-change": [3, 5], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 1.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7096374/elk-run-trail", "title": "Elk Run Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=45.710667,-123.900558", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7096374", "info-text": {"description": "This trail begins at an intersection with Alder Creek Trail as part of the Lower Nehalem Community Trust. Park on Tohl Rd and take Alder Creek Trail across the bridge. On the other side of the bridge, Elk Run Trail branches off to the right and heads towards the estuary. This part of the trail is muddy, narrow, and has a few improvised log bridges over wet and muddy areas. \r\n\nPick your way along the creek and keep on the lookout for wildlife, as the Alder Creek Nature Preserve is nearby. Follow the narrow track towards the estuary and soon you'll break out into the open. The trail here can be a bit hard to spot as you pick your way through driftwood logs. Soon, however, the trail leads up onto an old dike and you hike slightly above the mud through a narrow corridor of short trees. \r\n\nThe estuary stretches off to the south and Nehalem Bay is wide and open here. The views are amazing, you may spot shore birds, eagles, or hawks. This dike soon hits an old, grassy road that heads east around the peninsula. Blackberry bushes are prominent at the side of the road, ripe in August. \r\n\nHead right at the split in the road and take a short hike back out into the open estuary before hitting another old road and following it around to the Nehalem River. The trail ends here with a wide spot, a bench, and a nice area for a picnic at the rivers edge. You may see kayaks or other boaters traveling the Nehalem River.\r\n\nTurn around and head back the way you came, but stick right at the fork to follow the old road around the bottom of the hill. You'll shortly rejoin the road you were on previously. Stay right at the fork and this trail will head north and come out on the old utility road. Turn left and hike downhill towards the utility station at the end of Alder Creek Trail. The best views are obtained about 1/4 mile further uphill to a spot where, from left to right, you can see Tam McArthur rim, Broken Top, all 3 Sisters, Mt. Washington, Millican Crater, Black Crater, 3-Fingered Jack and Mt.
